Our World in Data: Key Crop Yields

Source: vignettes/key_crop_fileds.Rmd
key_crop_fileds.Rmd
library(cwdata)
library(ggplot2)
library(tidyverse)

Description

This data set is about the world’s key crop fields from 1961 to 2018. The data source is Our World in Data. It has nrow(key_crop_yields) rows and ncol(key_crop_yields) columns. The variables are about … You can take a look of the data as below.

key_crop_yields
#> # A tibble: 143,825 × 5
#>    entity      code   year crop     tonnes_per_hectare
#>    <chr>       <chr> <dbl> <chr>                 <dbl>
#>  1 Afghanistan AFG    1961 wheat                  1.02
#>  2 Afghanistan AFG    1961 rice                   1.52
#>  3 Afghanistan AFG    1961 maize                  1.4 
#>  4 Afghanistan AFG    1961 soybeans              NA   
#>  5 Afghanistan AFG    1961 potatoes               8.67
#>  6 Afghanistan AFG    1961 beans                 NA   
#>  7 Afghanistan AFG    1961 peas                  NA   
#>  8 Afghanistan AFG    1961 cassava               NA   
#>  9 Afghanistan AFG    1961 barley                 1.08
#> 10 Afghanistan AFG    1961 cocoa                 NA   
#> # … with 143,815 more rows

Examples

Examples with ggplots demonstrating how to use the package functions/datasets.

We could explore which kind of key crops has the highest production.

key_crop_yields %>% 
  filter(year == 2017) %>% 
  group_by(crop) %>% 
  summarise(tonnes_per_hectare = sum(tonnes_per_hectare, na.rm = TRUE)) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = forcats::fct_reorder(crop, desc(tonnes_per_hectare)), 
             y = tonnes_per_hectare)) + 
  geom_col() + 
  theme_bw() + 
  labs(x = "Crop", y = "Tonnes per hectare", title = "World's key crops production in 2017", caption = "Potatoes has the highest production")
